If by election day it looks as if Ross Perot cannot possibly win the election, will you change your mind and vote for one of the other candidates (George Bush, Bill Clinton) or will you vote for Perot in any case? (If No, Stay with Perot, Won't vote (vol.) Can't say, ask:) Would you still vote for Perot if the election seemed close and Clinton might win, or would you change your mind and vote for Bush?
SubPopulation: Asked of Form 2 half sample registered voters who intend to vote for Perot including leaners who said if it looks like Perot couldn't win they would stay with Perot, wouldn't vote, or couldn't say (13% of registered)
SurveySponsor: Times Mirror Center for the People & the Press
SourceDoc: People, The Press & Politics Campaign 1992 Poll
StudyNote: Re-interview of registered voters originally interviewed in a national sample October 8-11, 1992.

QuestionTxt: Which (1992 presidential) candidate did you switch from, that is, who were you supporting before the (presidential election) debate (October 19, 1992)?
SubPopulation: Asked of panel of registered voter debate watchers who changed their vote intent because of the debate--post debate re-interview October 19, 1992 (12% of registered voter debate watchers re-interviewed 10/19/92)
SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 19th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 19, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct.15-18, and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 19, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 19th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 19, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct.15-18, and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 19, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

QuestionTxt: If there were a major national or international crisis, which of the (1992) presidential candidates would you choose to handle it, George Bush, Bill Clinton, or Ross Perot?
SubPopulation: Panel of registered voter debate watchers-pre debate interview October 15-18, 1992
SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 19th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 19, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct.15-18, and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 19, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

SubPopulation: Panel of registered voter debate watchers-pre debate interview October 15-18, 1992 The order of the candidate's names was reversed in each half sample A and B * = less than .5 percent
SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 19th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 19, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct.15-18, and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 19, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

QuestionTxt: If by election day it looks as if Ross Perot cannot possibly win the election, will you change your mind and vote for one of the other candidates (George Bush, Bill Clinton) or will you vote for Perot in any case? (If Yes will vote for other, ask:) For whom would you most likely vote, George Bush or Bill Clinton? (If 'No, stay with Perot,' 'Won't vote (vol.),' 'Can't say,' ask:) Would you still vote for Perot if the election seemed close and Bush might win, or would you change your mind and vote for Clinton?
SubPopulation: Asked of Form 1 half sample registered voters who intend to vote for Perot including leaners who said if it looks like Perot couldn't win they would stay with Perot, wouldn't vote, or couldn't say (13% of registered)
SurveySponsor: Times Mirror Center for the People & the Press
SourceDoc: People, The Press & Politics Campaign 1992 Poll
StudyNote: Re-interview of registered voters originally interviewed in a national sample October 8-11, 1992.

QuestionTxt: I would like to read you three statements that compare the views of George Bush, Bill Clinton, and Ross Perot on improving the economy, and then ask you which comes closest to your own point of view. George Bush calls for a cut in the capital gains tax, an across-the-board tax cut, smaller government with less spending to reduce the deficit, less regulation of business, and legal reforms to eliminate costly and unnecessary lawsuits to help the economy. Bill Clinton calls for cutting the deficit in half over five years, a tax increase on the wealthy, a tax cut for the middle class, and spending more for education, job training, and building transportation systems to help the economy. Ross Perot calls for cutting spending and eliminating the entire deficit over five years, cutting Medicare and Social Security for people with higher incomes, and raising the gas tax 10 cents per gallon each year over five years to create jobs, aid education, and rebuild the transportation system. Which 1992 Presidential) candidate's economic plan do you most favor--George Bush's plan, Bill Clinton's plan, or Ross Perot's plan?

If the (1992) Presidential election were being held today, would you vote for the Republican candidates, George Bush and Dan Quayle, for the Democratic candidates, Bill Clinton and Al Gore, or for the Independent candidates, Ross Perot and James Stockdale? (If Other (vol.), Don't know/Refused, ask:) As of today, do you lean more to Bush and Quayle, the Republicans, to Clinton and Gore, the Democrats, or to Perot and Stockdale, the Independents?
SubPopulation: Asked of registered voters/plan to register on election day (80%) Candidates names were rotated in Form A and B half samples
StudyNote: Data is from the 1992 General Election Tracking survey--Independent three day tracking results

QuestionTxt: Based on what you saw and heard in the (1992 presidential candidate) debate (tonight October 11, 1992), which candidate do you think had the best answers on each of the following issues? Do you think Bush, Clinton or Perot had the best answers on the issue of... taxes?
SubPopulation: Panel of registered voter debate watchers post debate reinterview October 11, 1992 The respondents who said they watched hardly any/None of it/Don't know/Refused in the post debate interview were excluded from the panel
SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 11th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 11, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct 8-9 and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 11, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

QuestionTxt: (I am going to read off a list of phrases that might apply to the (1992 presidential) candidates and their performances in tonight's debate (October 11, 1992). As I read each one, tell me if you think it best describes George Bush, Bill Clinton or Ross Perot in the debate?)... Had the clearest and most concrete plans for solving the country's problems
SubPopulation: Panel of registered voter debate watchers post debate reinterview October 11, 1992 The respondents who said they watched hardly any/None of it/Don't know/Refused in the post debate interview were excluded from the panel
SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 11th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 11, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct 8-9 and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 11, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 11th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 11, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct 8-9 and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 11, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

QuestionTxt: As I read the list of issues again, please tell me if you think George Bush, Bill Clinton or Ross Perot would best handle each one. Which (1992) presidential candidate would best handle the issue of... education?
SubPopulation: Panel of registered voter debate watchers--pre debate interview 10/8-9/92
SampleDesc: Panel of registered voters who volunteered to be called immediately following the October 11th presidential debate.
StudyNote: Panel of national registered voters/plan to register on election day who saw the presidential debate October 11, 1992. The respondents were originally interviewed Oct 8-9 and said they planned to watch the debate Oct. 11, and agreed to be re-interviewed immediately following the debate. Only those who watched at least some of the debate are included in the panel with their pre and post debate responses.

QuestionTxt: During political campaigns, candidates are often accused of not having important qualities. For each quality I read, please tell me whether you are satisfied with both of the (1992) presidential candidates on that quality or not. When it comes to... promoting family values... are you satisfied with both presidential candidates on that quality, or are you dissatisfied with one or both of them? (If either candidates is unsatisfactory, ask:) Which candidate are you dissatisfied with on... promoting family values... --George Bush, Bill Clinton, or are you dissatisfied with both candidates on that quality?
SubPopulation: Asked of Form A half of registered voter sample

QuestionTxt: Two proposals have been made for allowing parents more choice in deciding what schools their children attend. I'd like to know which one, if either, you prefer. Proposal B would allow parents to choose among different public schools but would not provide vouchers for use in parochial or private schools. Which proposal do you prefer, Proposal A or Proposal B?

QuestionTxt: Two proposals have been made to help solve this country's health care problems. I'd like to know which one, if either, you prefer. Proposal A would require all employers to buy health insurance for their workers. It would allow the unemployed and the poor to enroll in a subsidized government plan. Proposal B would set up no government program, but would provide low-income people with tax credits of up to $3,750 to buy their own insurance from private companies. Those above the poverty line would receive a smaller subsidy. Which proposal do you prefer, Proposal A or Proposal B?

QuestionTxt: Which candidate for President would be more likely to try to raise taxes: George Bush or Bill Clinton, or wouldn't there be much difference between them?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
SampleDesc: National adult and members of the 1990 ANES panel
StudyNote: The sample included 1361 panel respondents first interviewed in the 1990 election survey plus 1126 new national cross section respondents A post-election survey with re-interviews of 2255 (91%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted in November.

I would like to read you two statements that compare George Bush's views on improving the economy to those of Bill Clinton, and then ask you which comes closest to your own point of view. George Bush calls for a cut in the capital gains tax, an across-the-board tax cut, and smaller government with less spending and regulation to help the economy. Bill Clinton calls for a tax increase on the wealthy, a tax cut for the middle class, and spending more for education, job training, and building transportation and communications systems to help the economy. QuestionTxt: Which presidential candidate do you think would do a better job at solving the problem of poverty--George Bush, Bill Clinton, or wouldn't there be any difference between them?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
SampleDesc: National adult and members of the 1990 ANES panel
StudyNote: The sample included 1361 panel respondents first interviewed in the 1990 election survey plus 1126 new national cross section respondents A post-election survey with re-interviews of 2255 (91%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted in November.

QuestionTxt: Which presidential candidate do you think would do a better job at reducing the budget deficit--George Bush, Bill Clinton, or wouldn't there be any difference between them?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
SampleDesc: National adult and members of the 1990 ANES panel
StudyNote: The sample included 1361 panel respondents first interviewed in the 1990 election survey plus 1126 new national cross section respondents A post-election survey with re-interviews of 2255 (91%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted in November.

QuestionTxt: If you were going to vote, who do you think you would vote for in the election for President? (Probe:) We all know the election is some time away and people are not certain at this point who they will vote for. Still, who do you think you will vote for in the election for President?
SubPopulation: Asked of those who said they will not vote or don't know whether they will vote (17%).
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
SampleDesc: National adult and members of the 1990 ANES panel
StudyNote: The sample included 1361 panel respondents first interviewed in the 1990 election survey plus 1126 new national cross section respondents A post-election survey with re-interviews of 2255 (91%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted in November.
